precontext: John had faced challenges in his career before. Each time, he approached them with determination. Now he stood before yet another one.
sentence: This will be his third try.
ending: And as the saying goes, the third time is a charm, so he knew he would succeed.
meanings_considered: put on trial or hear a case and sit as the judge at the trial of
explanation:
• "Try" as "make an effort" is strongly supported by the precontext, which emphasizes John's determination and repeated attempts to overcome challenges.  
• "Try" as "put on trial" is inconsistent with the context, as there is no mention of legal proceedings, judges, or cases being heard.  
• The ending reinforces the interpretation of "try" as an attempt, citing the common phrase "the third time is a charm," which refers to repeated efforts, not legal trials.
